Explanation: Students will develop proficiency in Java programming, including writing and using classes, working with strings, and utilizing arrays and ArrayLists.
Students will learn and apply fundamental concepts of computer science to solve problems using algorithms.
Students will gain the skill to read and write files and handle exceptions in Java programming.
Students will learn and practice recursive algorithms, which involve solving problems by breaking them down into smaller, similar subproblems.
Students will be introduced to data structures such as linked lists, which are essential for organizing and manipulating data efficiently.
Students will gain proficiency in Java programming language, which is essential for working with data structures.
Students will learn techniques for sorting and searching data structures efficiently.
Students will learn about hashing techniques and how to implement them in data structures.
Students will understand the concept of garbage collection and its importance in managing memory in data structures.
Students will learn the rudiments of analyzing algorithms and their efficiency in data structure operations.
Students will gain proficiency in the C programming language, which is a fundamental skill for advanced programming.
Students will learn how to program in a Unix environment, including file manipulation, process management, and system calls.
Students will learn how to use Git, a version control system commonly used in software development, to manage and track changes in their code.
Students will learn how to use Make, a build automation tool, to compile and manage complex software projects.
Students will acquire knowledge and skills related to networking protocols and communication using the TCP/IP protocol suite.
Students will learn how to construct logical arguments and formal proofs, which are essential skills in mathematics and computer science.
Students will develop the ability to work with sequences and summations, which are fundamental concepts in discrete mathematics and have applications in various areas of computer science.
Students will learn how to use mathematical induction to prove statements about integers and other mathematical objects, which is a powerful technique in mathematics and computer science.

Students will gain proficiency in solving recurrence relations, which are mathematical equations that describe the relationship between terms in a sequence, and are commonly used in analyzing the time complexity of algorithms.

Students will learn about the basic concepts and techniques in graph theory, such as isomorphism, traversability, planarity, and colorings, which are important in solving problems related to networks, optimization, and data structures.
Students will learn how to handle and manipulate deterministic and non-deterministic finite automata, which are essential concepts in computer science theory.
Students will gain proficiency in using regular expressions, a powerful tool for pattern matching and text manipulation.
Students will develop the skill of working with context-free grammars, which are used to describe the syntax of programming languages and other formal languages.
Students will learn how to handle and manipulate Turing machines, a theoretical model of computation that forms the basis of modern computer science.
Students will acquire the skill of understanding and analyzing the complexity of algorithms and problems, which is crucial in designing efficient solutions.
Students will learn how to design and manipulate digital circuits using Boolean algebra, Karnaugh maps, and basic gates.
Students will gain proficiency in programming in assembly language and understanding instruction sets.
Students will learn about the design and implementation of processors, including single-cycle and multi-cycle designs.
Students will understand the concept of pipelined processors and their advantages.
Students will learn about the principles and implementation of cache memory and virtual memory systems.
Students will learn how to perform operations on matrices, such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and inversion.
Students will develop the skill of calculating probabilities using linear algebra concepts, such as conditional probability and probability distributions.
Students will gain proficiency in conducting statistical analysis using various methods and techniques.
Students will learn how to interpret and analyze data to draw meaningful conclusions.
Students will develop proficiency in using statistical software for data analysis and visualization.
Students will learn how to design studies and experiments to collect relevant data for statistical analysis.
Students will enhance their ability to think critically and make logical decisions based on quantitative information.
Students will gain proficiency in SQL, which is a fundamental skill in working with databases and querying data.
Students will learn about XML (eXtensible Markup Language) and its use in databases, allowing them to work with XML data and integrate it into database systems.
Students will learn how to design large-scale distributed systems, including the use of abstractions and implementation techniques.
Students will gain proficiency in designing and implementing fault-tolerant distributed systems.
Students will learn about different communication models used in distributed systems, such as sockets, remote procedure calls, and distributed shared memory.
Students will develop skills in designing and implementing distributed file systems.
Students will learn about scalable distributed databases and the techniques used to build them.
Students will gain proficiency in using MATLAB for implementing machine learning algorithms.
Students will learn and understand various machine learning algorithms such as support vector machines, neural networks, and Bayesian networks.
Students will develop skills in analyzing and interpreting data to make informed decisions in the context of machine learning.
Students will enhance their programming skills through implementing machine learning algorithms in MATLAB.
Students will learn how to apply statistical methods and techniques to analyze and interpret data in the field of machine learning.
Students will gain proficiency in Ruby on Rails, a popular web application framework, through hands-on projects and exercises.
Students will learn and apply Agile development methodologies, including iterative and incremental development, to effectively manage software projects.

Students will learn and practice behavior-driven development (BDD) techniques, which involve collaboration between developers, testers, and business stakeholders to define and validate software requirements.
Students will understand the principles and concepts of service-oriented architecture (SOA) and learn how to design and develop software systems using this architectural style.
Students will learn about DevOps practices, including continuous integration, continuous delivery, and infrastructure automation, to improve software development and deployment processes.

Students will develop skills in designing software systems, specifically focusing on graphical user interfaces.
Students will learn how to design effective interactions between users and computer systems.
Students will gain proficiency in designing dialogues and conversations within user interfaces.

Students will gain proficiency in implementing and managing security features in operating systems.

Students will develop the ability to classify patterns and objects based on their visual features.
Students will gain proficiency in identifying and categorizing objects in images or videos.
Students will learn how to analyze the motion of objects in a sequence of images.
Students will learn how to represent and model three-dimensional objects using computer vision techniques.

Students will learn machine learning techniques used in NLP, such as supervised machine learning, Bayesian models, hidden Markov models, neural networks, RNNs, and transformers.
